Perturbations and stability conditions of k-essence and kinetic gravity braiding models in two-field measure theory
R. Cordero 1,∗ J. De-Santiago 2,3,† O. G. Miranda 3,‡ and M. Serrano-Crivelli 1§ 1 Departamento de F́ısica, Escuela Superior de F́ısica y Matemáticas del Instituto Politécnico Nacional
Unidad Adolfo López Mateos, Edificio 9, 07738 Ciudad de México, Mexico 2 Consejo Nacional de Ciencia y Tecnoloǵıa. Av. Insurgentes Sur 1582, 03940, Ciudad de México, México and
3 Departamento de F́ısica, Centro de Investigación y de Estudios Avanzados del IPN Apdo. Postal 14-740 07000 Ciudad de México, Mexico
We study cosmological perturbations for k-essence and kinetic gravity braiding models in the context of the two-field measure theory (TMT). Considering scalar perturbations and the uniform field gauge, we obtain the sound speed of the fields and present a stability analysis by means of the kinetic matrix and the mass eigenvalues. For k-essence models, in the two-field measure theory, the speed of propagation of the field is modified completely due to the new measure field and it gives rise to crucial differences with respect to the case without new measure. The stability analysis gives a physical viable model for the Universe. For the kinetic gravity braiding models in the two-field measure theory we get that, in general, the speed of perturbations is equal to the speed of light which is a consequence of the properties of the new measure field. In the later case, there is always a ghost field. Furthermore, we calculate general expressions for the mass eigenvalues and find, for an explicit example, the existence of tachyonic instabilities.
I. INTRODUCTION
The discovery of the Universe’s accelerating expansion [1, 2] became one of the most interesting current problems in cosmology [3–8]. To explain this behaviour, scientists have proposed many different dark energy models that can be classified into two kinds: the matter and gravity-modified models (see, for example, [9–16]).
A recent alternative explanation to the observations of an accelerating expanding Universe is the Two Field Measure Theory (TMT) [17, 18]. This model includes a new measure, Φ, in its action, besides the usual general relativity measure ( √ −g). Different actions have been analyzed in this context [19–24]. Recently, it has been argued that this kind of formalism is useful in string and brane theories to generate a string tension that appears dynamically [25–27]. One of the more interesting properties is that for general k-essence models, this proposal unifies dark matter and dark energy [17, 18]. Moreover, the role of fermionic matter in TMT has also been studied and it was found that its incorporation may lead to a dynamically generated dark energy, for instance, through the neutrino sector [28, 29]. However, to test its viability as an acceptable cosmological model, it is necessary to study the perturbations of these models to see if they evolve according to the observations without developing ghosts or exponential growth. For example, there exist ghost modes in the self-accelerating branch of the Dvali-Gabadadze-Porrati cosmological model [30], in a nonlinear massive gravity [31] and in the linear massive gravity with a de Sitter background spacetime [32]. Several aspects of perturbations in TMT models have been studied in the k-essence context in [17, 33] by a different approach to the presented here.
Some of the most studied models with the possibility to drive the late-time accelerated expansion of the Universe lie in the category of Horndeski’s models [34], which are scalar-tensor theories with second-order equations of motion. From the classification found in [35], we will focus on the first two types of Lagrangians, the k-essence [36–46] and the kinetic braiding models [47], which are not excluded by recent observations of gravitational waves [48–52]. Other physical preferences could be extracted from the study of the Hubble constant tension in Hordenski’s models which can be found in [53, 54]. The k-essence models are characterized by the action1
S = ∫ K(ϕ,X) √ −gd4x , (1)

where the Lagrangian K is a general function of the k-essence field ϕ and its kinetic term X = −1/2gµν∂µϕ∂νϕ, where gµν is the metric of the spacetime with signature (−+ ++). Later on, it was realized that this model belongs to a wider class of models called Galileons [56–59]. In particular, some k-essence models can provide a mechanism to produce a unified description of dark energy and dark matter [44, 45, 60]. The second very interesting subclass of Horndeski’s models is the so-called kinetic gravity braiding models. These models have an action of the form
S = − ∫ G3(ϕ,X) ϕ √ −gd4x , (2)
that includes a D’Alambertian operator and a general function of the field and its kinetic term [47]. 2 In this model, the pressure depends on second-order derivatives of the scalar fields, and the expression for the energy density contains the Hubble parameter. These characteristics produce exciting features analyzed in Refs. [61–64].
In this paper, we study the cosmological scalar perturbations of k-essence and kinetic gravity braiding models in the context of two field measure theory. To do this we perturb the action following the procedure in [65]. In particular, we obtain propagation speed of the fields, the kinetic matrix and the mass eigenvalues for the kinetic gravity braiding model in TMT. We illustrate our calculations for a particular braiding field.
The paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we develop the main ingredients of TMT. In Section III, we compute the scalar perturbations and the speed of sound of the field for k-essence models and compare them with the case when the TMT is included. In Section IV, we calculate the perturbations of the kinetic gravity braiding model in TMT and the kinetic matrix. In particular, we present the procedure to obtain the mass eigenvalues. Finally, we give our conclusions. Additionally, as a guide to the reader, we include table I with the symbols used in this work.
II. THE TWO FIELD MEASURE THEORY
In this Section we describe the main features of TMT, that we will use throughout this work, following the discussions presented in [22, 66]. In this theory, the action has two measures: the term with the usual metric gµν and an extra term with a new measure Φ, in the same space-time,
S = ∫ L1 √ −gd4x+ ∫ L2Φd4x. (3)
It is possible to construct the new measure using four scalar fields, ξa (a = 1, 2, 3, 4),
Φ = µναβ ijkl∂µξ i∂νξ j∂αξ k∂βξ l. (4)
In the present work we consider the Lagrangians L1, L2 to be independent from the fields ξa and each of them to be independent of each other. The relations between the fields come from the equations of motion.
As shown in [67], the variation of the action produces the equation of motion

We will repeat the procedure for the model including the new measure and compare the results.

This value for the sound speed makes the kinetic gravity braiding model with new measure unsuitable to represent the Dark Matter of the Universe, as the perturbations will not grow as expected from the structure formations. V. CONCLUSIONS
The nature of the late time accelerating expansion of the Universe is one of the most challenging aspects of modern cosmology. One of the more appealing characteristics of Two Field Measure Theory is the possibility to have a unifying description of dark matter and dark energy. In this paper we have studied the perturbations of k-essence and braiding fields in the context of a Two Field Measure Theory. We have found the stability characteristics and the speed of sound of the scalars fields.
In the original Horndeski theory, the speed of perturbations is a function of the field LagrangianK(ϕ,X) orG3(ϕ,X) as well as their derivatives, as it is summarized in table II, presenting a rich variety in the speeds of sound depending on the particular Lagrangians. When the new measure Φ is added, however, both cases present a fixed behaviour. For the k-essence models we obtained that the field follows geodesics, a result already obtained in [17]. This allows the field to be a good candidate for the Dark Matter as it can grow its perturbations and form the structure of the Universe. In contrast, kinetic gravity braiding model G3 φ has a unitary speed of perturbations. This characteristic is a consequence of the new measure field which fixed the value of the matter Lagrangian.
For the braiding models we studied further their stability conditions. We obtained that, in the presence of the new measure, there will always appear a ghost instability. The field perturbations of the braiding field plus new measure, can be mapped to a two field theory with a ghost field and a canonical field, both with complicated mass expressions written in Eq. (77). When the masses squared are negative we are in the presence of a tachyon instability.
To shed some light on the tachyonic stability of the Braiding model, we studied a particular example in which the field density evolves as a power law in the scale factor plus a cosmological constant. In that case, we computed the squared masses of the resulting fields, obtaining that they change their sign as the Universe evolves. When the density of the Braiding model is low, the tachyonic instability can be limited to the early Universe.
Both, ghost and tachyonic instabilities disfavour the braiding + TMT model as explanation for either dark energy or dark matter, since its energy is unbounded from below. An equally important problem for the braiding field to represent the dark matter is that its sound speed is equal to the speed of light, this prevents the perturbations to grow and form the structure of the Universe, despite its background density to evolve as dust with 1/a3 as can be seen in Eq. (83) for γ = −1/2. The tachyonic and braiding instabilities might be alleviated if we had considered in our calculations a Universe with more fields besides the braiding field, however this study was outside of the scope of this work.
13
The dark energy nature is one of the most intriguing question in modern cosmology. The TMT theory has exciting properties. For example, any k-essence model in the context of TMT can produce a unification of dark matter and dark energy and explain the growth of structure in the Universe.
